conclusion: Shadows are formed when an object blocks light, creating a region where the light source is not directly visible.
The size and position of the shadow depend on the position of the light source relative to the object and the surface on which the shadow is cast.
The light source is initially positioned at a certain distance from the objects, casting shadows A, B, C, and D on the ground.
The shadows are elongated in the direction opposite to the light source.
When the light source moves backward (away from the objects), the angle at which the light rays hit the objects changes.
This change in angle affects both the position and the size of the shadows.
As the light source moves backward, the shadows will shift closer to the objects.
The shadows will become smaller due to the increased distance between the light source and the objects.
Summary: Shadows A, B, C, and D will move closer to their respective objects and become smaller.
Final Answer: When the light source moves backward above the objects, shadows A, B, C, and D will shift closer to the objects and decrease in size.
